title: 104_hr851
content:
The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" establishes a project. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" establishes up to 10 pilot projects to investigate the use of rural health care provider telemedicine networks for physician consultative services under Medicare in rural areas. A rural health care provider telemedicine network includes providers in rural areas collaborating with a multispecialty tertiary care provider for patient care and transportation. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" allows rural health care providers to collaborate with multispecialty tertiary care providers for patient referral, joint communications systems, and transportation in designated rural or underserved areas. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" allows rural health care providers to collaborate with multispecialty tertiary care providers for patient referral, joint communications systems, and transportation in designated rural or underserved areas. Medicare payment for participants is addressed in Section 3. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" enables rural health care providers to receive payments from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for physician consultative services provided to Medicare beneficiaries in rural areas, regardless of the location of the consulting physician. The Secretary will establish a methodology for determining payment amounts, including covering reasonable costs for signal transmission facilities. Payments may also be made to nonphysician providers. The Secretary will establish a methodology for determining payment amounts under the Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995, including covering costs for signal transmission facilities for physician consultative services. Payments can also be made to nonphysician providers. Eligibility of networks to participate in a pilot project under the Act requires submission of an application with necessary information and agreeing to provide required data to the Secretary. The term "rural area" is defined as per the Social Security Act. Criteria for selecting participants will be established. SEC. 5. CRITERIA FOR SELECTING PARTICIPANTS.

Priority given to networks enabling consultations between patients and specialists through detailed data transmission. Existing networks can participate in pilot projects.

SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Secretary must submit an interim report to Congress within 24 months of making payments for pilot project services, detailing participating projects and networks, expenses, and patient numbers. A final report is due within 1 year after project termination, analyzing cost-effectiveness, impact on patient care quality, and providing recommendations for changes in the Medicare program related to telemedicine. The Secretary must provide an interim report to Congress within 24 months of initiating pilot projects, detailing project impact on patient care quality and recommendations for changes in the Medicare program related to telemedicine, including cost estimates. Authorization of appropriations from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for a total of $51,000,000 for a demonstration project under this Act, with up to $1,000,000 for administrative purposes.
